# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a Julia solution using DataFrames package. Note that the function `filter` and `rowwise` are used to apply conditions on rows, create new columns, and modify existing ones respectively.

```julia
using DataFrames, Tables
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # filter data by manufacturer and model
    df = filter(r -> r.manufacturer == "audi" && (r.model == "a4" || r.model == "a4 quattro"), df)

    # create a new column
    df[:new_column] = true

    return df
end
```
You can call the function like this:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"], 
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_cars = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
After calling the function, `df_cars` will contain only rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". It also adds a new column named `new_column` with all values set to `true`.
